trans-unit.source: How to silently install the Azure AD Application Proxy Connector | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to silently install the Azure AD Application Proxy Connector | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Covers how to perform a silent installation of Azure AD Application Proxy Connector to provide secure remote access to your on-premises apps.
trans-unit.target: Covers how to perform a silent installation of Azure AD Application Proxy Connector to provide secure remote access to your on-premises apps.

trans-unit.source: How to silently install the Azure AD Application Proxy Connector
trans-unit.target: How to silently install the Azure AD Application Proxy Connector

trans-unit.source: You want to be able to send an installation script to multiple Windows servers or to Windows Servers that don't have user interface enabled.
trans-unit.target: You want to be able to send an installation script to multiple Windows servers or to Windows Servers that don't have user interface enabled.

trans-unit.source: This topic explains how to create a Windows PowerShell script that enables unattended installation and installs and registers your Azure AD Application Proxy Connector.
trans-unit.target: This topic explains how to create a Windows PowerShell script that enables unattended installation and installs and registers your Azure AD Application Proxy Connector.

trans-unit.source: Enabling Access
trans-unit.target: Enabling Access

trans-unit.source: Application Proxy works by installing a slim Windows Server service called the Connector inside your network.
trans-unit.target: Application Proxy works by installing a slim Windows Server service called the Connector inside your network.

trans-unit.source: For the Application Proxy Connector to work it has to be registered with your Azure AD directory using a global administrator and password.
trans-unit.target: For the Application Proxy Connector to work it has to be registered with your Azure AD directory using a global administrator and password.

trans-unit.source: Ordinarily this is entered during Connector installation in a pop up dialog box.
trans-unit.target: Ordinarily this is entered during Connector installation in a pop up dialog box.

trans-unit.source: Instead, you can use Windows PowerShell to create a credential object to enter your registration information, or you can create your own token and use it to enter your registration information.
trans-unit.target: Instead, you can use Windows PowerShell to create a credential object to enter your registration information, or you can create your own token and use it to enter your registration information.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Install the Connector without registration
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Install the Connector without registration

trans-unit.source: Install the Connector MSIs without registering the Connector as follows:
trans-unit.target: Install the Connector MSIs without registering the Connector as follows:

trans-unit.source: Open a command prompt.
trans-unit.target: Open a command prompt.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command in which the /q means quiet installation - the installation will not prompt you to accept the End User License Agreement.
trans-unit.target: Run the following command in which the /q means quiet installation - the installation will not prompt you to accept the End User License Agreement.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Register the Connector with Azure Active Directory
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Register the Connector with Azure Active Directory

trans-unit.source: This can be accomplished using either of the following methods:
trans-unit.target: This can be accomplished using either of the following methods:

trans-unit.source: Register the Connector using a Windows PowerShell credential object
trans-unit.target: Register the Connector using a Windows PowerShell credential object

trans-unit.source: Register the Connector using a token created offline
trans-unit.target: Register the Connector using a token created offline

trans-unit.source: Register the Connector using a Windows PowerShell credential object
trans-unit.target: Register the Connector using a Windows PowerShell credential object

trans-unit.source: Create the Windows PowerShell Credentials object, by running the following, where "username" and "password" should be replaced with the username and password for your directory:
trans-unit.target: Create the Windows PowerShell Credentials object, by running the following, where "username" and "password" should be replaced with the username and password for your directory:

trans-unit.source: Go to **C:\Program Files\Microsoft AAD App Proxy Connector** and run the script using the PowerShell credentials object you created: where $cred is the name of the PowerShell credentials object you created:
trans-unit.target: Go to **C:\Program Files\Microsoft AAD App Proxy Connector** and run the script using the PowerShell credentials object you created: where $cred is the name of the PowerShell credentials object you created:

trans-unit.source: Register the Connector using a token created offline
trans-unit.target: Register the Connector using a token created offline

trans-unit.source: Create an offline token using the AuthenticationContext class using the values in the code snippet:
trans-unit.target: Create an offline token using the AuthenticationContext class using the values in the code snippet:

trans-unit.source: Once you have the token create a SecureString using the token:
trans-unit.target: Once you have the token create a SecureString using the token:

trans-unit.source: Run the following Windows PowerShell command, where SecureToken is the name of the token you created above and tenantID is your tenant's GUID:
trans-unit.target: Run the following Windows PowerShell command, where SecureToken is the name of the token you created above and tenantID is your tenant's GUID:
